1111.title: Red meets the wolf

11112.content:
However, he failed to notice the fact that his glasses were slipping, so engrossed was he in his pursuit. The eyepiece, nonetheless, slid further and further away from his ears, and further and further down his muzzle, unused to such speeds.

Just as he did not notice his glasses slipping, the wolf did not register the tiny rock jutting out of the ground in front of him…that is, until one of his front paws slammed directly on top of it.

"YEEEEOWW!" the wolf's pained yelp rang through the air, and he tumbled forward, the momentum propelling him forward a good few feet. At the same time, his glasses were violently dislodged from the bridge of his snout; they, too, flew through the air, landing on the forest floor a few feet in front of him.

The wolf grunted as he hit the ground belly-first, wincing as his muzzle smacked upon the ground. "Ooh, that'll leave a mark…" the wolf mumbled, staggering to his hind feet/paws. He winced again, noticing the ache in his muzzle. Reaching up with his hands/front paws, he gently massaged his snout, letting out a sigh of relief after a few seconds. "Nope, nothing's fractured. Still hurts like heck, though," he grimaced, continuing to massage his muzzle. "Geez, what did I step on? A stick, or a rock, or something like…"

He stopped abruptly, his eyes focusing on his hands, still on his muzzle. Only problem: they seemed a bit more blurry than usual. "Crap! Where're my glasses?" He felt around his ears, hoping that he might at least find them dangling from one of the pointed appendages.

No such luck; they were nowhere to be found. The wolf felt a brief surge of panic; those glasses hadn't been easy to come across, and he couldn't see a thing without them. Long story short: if they were lost or worse, broken, he was out of luck.

Willing himself to stay calm, the wolf dropped to all fours, tail held high in the air. He scuttled about, sniffing wildly, as his tail waved to and fro, bristling with nervous energy.

"Crap, crap, crap," the wolf hissed, exposing his teeth in a worried grimace after several seconds of searching had passed, with no results. "Where are they, where are they, where are…"

CRUNCH!

The wolf stopped dead as he felt one of his back paws fall upon something hard, flimsy, and very breakable. Slowly-very slowly-he moved his back paw up off the ground, at the same time turning himself around to get a better look at the unfortunate object.

"Please, please, please don't let that be my glasses," the wolf muttered, trying to fight back the sense of panic growing within his chest. "Please, please, please don't let those be my glasses," he said again, repeating it as though it were the most sacred of mantras. "Please, please, please…"

After what seemed like minutes (but was, in reality, only a few seconds,) he was finally staring directly at the destroyed object. His vision was still blurry, so he couldn't make it out exactly, but he could make out the color: namely, a light brown.

Crap, he thought to himself, anxious. That was the same color as his glasses rims! Anxiety churning at an even greater intensity than before, he squinted his eyes as hard as he could…and promptly let out a huge sigh of relief.

What he had stepped on was not a pair of glasses, but rather a couple of small sticks. The broken twigs were hard and brittle, which readily explained the unpleasant crunching noise they had produced when trampled upon.

The wolf let loose another relieved sigh. "Heh…heh heh," he chuckled nervously, slowly backing away from the offending twigs. "Freakin' sticks…." He turned around, glancing left and right as he did so. "Now, I've just gotta keep looking around, and hope I don't actually step on-eh?" His lupine ears perked up as one of his front paws brushed across something. Puzzled, he glanced downwards. There, right in front of him, sat his glasses, a bit dirty but otherwise unharmed.

Yet another sigh of relief escaped the wolf's muzzle. "Oh, good," he breathed, quickly scooping them up in his paw and standing back up on his hind paws as he did so. "Good thing I wasn't searching like that the whole time; otherwise, I'd be crap outta luck!" Chuckling from relief, he stuck out his tongue and wet a couple of his fingers before using the padded digits to wipe the dirt and leaves off the lenses. Smiling, he blew on the lenses a bit to dry them before placing them back on his face. "Ah, that's better…"

He took a deep whiff. "Ah, that smells really nice…" Ears perking, he sniffed the air some more. "…and whatever it is, it's really close by!" He took stock of his surroundings; forest floor all around him, a few trees in back of him, a line of trees at his front, what looked like a dirt road in front of that tree line…

"That's it!" he exclaimed suddenly, his tail swishing about in frenzied excitement. "That's where its coming from!" With his tongue lolling out of his mouth and his nose lost in that wondrous smell, he dropped back to all fours, tensed his limbs, and leapt forward. He grinned as he sailed towards his destination. HereIcomehereIcomehereIcomehereIcome…

He'd just about reached the dirt road, and he thought he might even make a perfect landing, four paws and all. Incidentally, no sooner had this thought flitted through his head than a frightened scream rang through the air.

Letting out a startled yelp of his own, the wolf lost his concentration and tumbled, quite un-gracefully, the rest of the way, smashing into the ground back-first and raising a cloud of dust. "GAH! That's the second time today!" he grumbled, hoisting himself up on his hands. He winced suddenly, massaging the area between his neck and shoulder with a padded hand. "Geez, at this rate, I'll end up with arthritis or something…"

His ears perked up, and, on impulse, he glanced to the side. As soon as he did so, his eyes widened, as he saw what could only have been the source of the scream…and it wasn't quite what he'd expected.

There, standing only a few feet away from him on the dirt road, was a young girl, about twelve or thirteen years old. Her attire was simple, yet tasteful: an earthy-brown homespun dress, well-worn leather shoes, and, most striking of all, a red cowl that terminated in a short cape. She carried a simple, handwoven basket in her hands, which quivered along with her arms. From beneath that hood, her light blue eyes stared at the wolf, widened in fear.

The wolf turned to the girl, blinking in surprise. Still rubbing the back of his neck, he ventured an uncertain greeting. "Um…hi?"

"H-hi…" the girl stammered, the basket still shaking in her hands.

The wolf groaned quietly; out of all the things he could of said, he had to go and say 'hi'? It certainly wasn't doing the poor girl any favors. The wolf shook his head, taking a deep breath through his nostrils…

…and immediately straightening, ears shooting up. That wonderful smell was back, and it was really close by! The wolf's eyes flitted about, trying to see where the smell might be coming from, before they finally settled on the basket the girl was holding.

Engrossed in the delectable scent, the wolf practically lunged in the girl's direction, barely noticing the girl's terrified yelp. Dropping further to the ground, the human-like wolf put his snout to the basket, taking a deep whiff.

He practically moaned as his nose was overpowered by the sweet smell. "Ohhh, that's good…" He took another deep whiff, helpless to prevent another moan from escaping his muzzle. Whatever was in that basket, he wanted it, and wanted it bad. Unable to help himself, he took a third whiff, this time opening his muzzle a bit. He paid little heed to the tiny amount of saliva, which had pooled over the last few seconds in his mouth, dripping out

The girl, at this point, was even more nervous than before. What was he doing? Getting really close to her, sniffing at her, drooling near her? It was almost like he was… the girl paled, not wanting to think any further on the subject.

Meanwhile, the wolf, oblivious to this reaction, finally decided he'd had enough. Backing up and standing up to his full height, he wiped a hand across his mouth, wiping away the saliva and wondering, offhand, just how long he'd been producing it. "Man, that smells awesome," he mumbled, a goofy grin forming across his muzzle. "Whatcha got in there?"

"In here?" The girl blinked in confusion. "Oh! You mean in the basket!" She glanced down at it, now feeling more confused than frightened. "Um, a batch of cookies I made for my grandma."

"You made those?" the wolf exclaimed. "Musta done a good job, if the smell's anything to go by."

In spite of herself, the girl smiled. "Nah; it's her recipe, but she makes them the best."

The wolf shrugged. "Hey, a cookie's a cookie; so long as they're not rock hard and tasteless, it's all good."

The girl blinked. "Um, thanks, I guess. Still, I hope they make her feel a little better

"Eh?" The wolf's eyes widened, his curiosity piqued. "Is something the matter with her?" Great; freak the girl out some more, why don't you.

The girl straightened, a bit of firmness coming into her expression. "W-why do you want to know? You're not planning to do anything to her, are you?"

"What!?" The wolf couldn't believe what he was hearing. "Of course not! Why would you think something like that?" He knew wolves weren't exactly the most popular critters around these parts, but still… "Look, I'm just curious; there's no reason to jump to conclusions or anything."

111121.content:
"Well," the girl sniffed, the firmness remaining, "if you really wanna know, it's nothing serious; she just sprained her ankle the other day, and it's kind of hard for her to get around."

"Sprained ankle?" the wolf winced. "I've been there; how's she holding up?"

The girl gulped; why was he showing so much concern for her? "Just fine; she's uncomfortable, that's all." Her eyes narrowed. "Why do you care? Besides that, who are you? Why aren't you wearing any clothes? And why do you have glasses?"

The wolf laughed nervously, holding up both of his hands. "Whoa, kid, one question at a time." He thought for a second. "Then again, I probably could have explained a few things." Clearing his throat, he began answering her questions.

"First off, my name's Janus. Pleased to meetcha." He held out a hand. "And yours?"

The girl eyed his hand suspiciously for a few seconds, only reaching out once she'd stared at it for a bit. "My name's Red. I…guess it's nice to meet you, Janus."

Janus grinned, exposing his sharp teeth and causing Red to flinch a bit. "That wasn't so hard, was it?" Without waiting for her to answer, he immediately picked up on her second question. "Why aren't I wearing clothes? Um, please note…" he gestured to his body. "Notice the fur. Notice the paws. Notice the tail and ears. Notice the freaking muzzle. I'm a wolf; why would I bother with clothing?"

Red shrugged. "Well, I wouldn't have a problem if you walked like a normal wolf, but you're standing up like a person. Wouldn't people see…certain things?"

Janus groaned. "Oh, c'mon! It's not that bad! Seriously, I don't get what it is with you humans and your obsession with covering up your bodies. I mean, yeah, clothes do look snazzy, but the minute they come off, you're running and ducking for cover." He grunted, folding his arms. "And anyway, you can't see anything; if you can take your eyes off my handsome mug for a second, you could plainly see that I'm decent, so to speak."

Raising her eyebrows skeptically, Red nonetheless slowly moved her eyes from Janus's face all the way down to… a certain point on his body. A jolt of dread slinked up her spine. He'd better not be lying about this…

Fortunately, he wasn't, and Red breathed a quiet sigh of relief; true to Janus's words, his fur covered his body in such a way that specific sights were hidden from curious (or insane) eyes.

Janus smiled. "See? Didn't I tell ya? Nothing to see here." He chuckled, scratching the back of his head. "And before we get too off-subject here…you wanted to know about my glasses, right?" The girl nodded, now more curious than anything. "Well, it's simple, really; I can't see a damn thing without 'em."

Red blinked, confused. "Don't wolves smell their way around most of the time?"

Janus shrugged. "Well, admittedly, I do use my nose a lot, too, but there are some things that are best experienced with these." He pointed to both his eyes. "Besides, if I just used my nose, chances are I'd come across a few too many…unpleasant… smells, if you catch my drift."

The girl grimaced. "I'm not sure I want to…"

The humanoid wolf waved a dismissive paw. "Eh, I don't blame ya; some things you just don't wanna hear about." He chuckled, but quickly froze as he took in another whiff of the cookies. "Oh man, those smell so good. How'd you make them?"

The girl opened her mouth, but quickly shut it. "I-I'm sorry, but I don't know if my grandma would appreciate me sharing her recipe with a stranger. She's had it for years, you know."

Must be a heckuva recipe, Janus mused, brow furrowed in thought. Still, it makes sense she wouldn't wanna share it. But man oh man, I want those cookies so bad…ah!

A grin slowly spread across Janus's muzzle as a light bulb flashed in his mind. "Say, kid," he began, his smile slowly widening. "If I asked her nicely, you think she'd be willing to share her recipe with me?"

"H-huh?" Red snapped to attention, instantly on guard. "Well, I dunno; I mean, it's not like it's a jealously guarded secret or anything, but I don't know if she'd want to share it with someone who…erm…"

"Might wanna eat her?" Janus spoke up, finishing her sentence. "Relax, I don't plan on eating anyone today; I'll just make myself a bit more presentable, head off, and hope she doesn't mind me dropping in." His ears twitched. "Oh, that reminds me: where did you say her house was again?"

Red narrowed her eyes. "I didn't, and honestly, I don't know if I feel like telling you. I mean, you seem nice enough, but I don't wanna take the chance that…"

"I just keep following this road until I come across a little cottage, right?" Janus butted in, startling the girl.

"Y-yes…how did you know..?"

The bipedal wolf shrugged. "Eh, I've passed by it a couple of times in the past; never really gave it much thought, though." Upon catching her wary look, Janus sighed. "Look, kid, I give you my word; I'm not gonna hurt your grandma, OK?"

Red glared at him, but nonetheless nodded. "Alright, if you say so. You'd better not be lying, though…" Keeping her eyes on Janus, she slowly strolled past him, heading on her way down the dirt road.

He watched her go, blinking. "Well, she didn't seem too happy; maybe I should stay off the road." He rubbed his hand-paws together, a smile quickly forming on his muzzle. "Anyway, first things first; gotta find me some clothes, first." Tail wagging, he darted back into the trees, peering out at the road from behind a large pine tree. "Should be easy enough; just gotta wait for an unsuspecting passerby to stroll by, and then I can jump 'em, take their clothes, and be on my merry way." He grimaced. "They're probably not gonna be too happy, though...." he shrugged. "Ah, I'll cross that bridge when I come to it. Besides, it wouldn't be the first time I've gotten humans pissed at me…" He winced as he remembered the sight of an angry lumberjack, axe in hand, chasing him through the woods.

In spite of his trepidation, Janus snorted. "Hey, it was his fault for making such delicious-smelling flapjacks…" He grinned, rubbing his stomach. "And man, were those worth the effort!" He could almost taste it as he thought back to it: the fluffy pancake, the butter and syrup slathered across it…

His ears perked up suddenly. "Eh?" Snapping out of his reverie, he looked up…and grinned as he spotted exactly what he'd been looking for.

"Nothin' personal, stranger," Janus muttered as he tensed, ready to pounce on the young man that strolled, unsuspecting, across the dirt road. "But I need me some duds…and you've got exactly what I need."

Later...

122.content:
HARD BY a great forest dwelt a poor wood-cutter with his wife and his two children. The boy was called Hansel and the girl Gretel. He had little to bite and to break, and once when great dearth fell on the land, he could no longer procure even daily bread. Now when he thought over this by night in his bed, and tossed about in his anxiety, he groaned and said to his wife: "What is to become of us? How are we to feed our poor children, when we no longer have anything even for ourselves?" "I'11 tell you what, husband," answered the woman, "early to-morrow morning we will take the children out into the forest to where it is the thickest; there we will light a fire for them, and give each of them one more piece of bread, and then we will go to our work and leave them alone. They will not find the way home again, and we shall be rid of them." "No, wife," said the man, "I will not do that; how can I bear to leave my children alone in the forest--the wild animals would soon come and tear them to pieces." "0, you fool!" said she, "then we must all four die of hunger, you may as well plane the planks for our coffins," and she left him no peace until he consented. "But I feel very sorry for the poor children, all the same," said the man.
The two children had also not been able to sleep for hunger, and had heard what their step-mother had said to their father. Gretel wept bitter tears, and said to Hansel: "Now all is over with us." "Be quiet, Gretel," said Hansel, "do not distress yourself, I will soon find a way to help us." And when the old folks had fallen asleep, he got up, put on his little coat, opened the door below, and crept outside. The moon shone brightly, and the white pebbles which lay in front of the house glittered like real silver pennies. Hansel stooped and stuffed the little pocket of his coat with as many as he could get in. Then he went back and said to Gretel: "Be comforted, dear little sister, and sleep in peace, God will not forsake us," and he lay down again in his bed. When day dawned, but before the sun had risen, the woman came and awoke the two children, saying: "Get up, you sluggards! We are going into the forest to fetch wood." She gave each a little piece of bread, and said: "There is something for your dinner, but do not eat it up before then, for you will get nothing else." Gretel took the bread under her apron, as Hansel had the pebbles in his pocket. Then they all set out together on the way to the forest. When they had walked a short time, Hansel stood still and peeped back at the house, and did so again and again. His father said: "Hansel, what are you looking at there and staying behind for? Pay attention, and do not forget how to use your legs." "Ah, father," said Hansel, "I am looking at my little white cat, which is sitting up on the roof, and wants to say good-bye to me." The wife said: "Fool, that is not your little cat, that is the morning sun which is shining on the chimneys." Hansel, however, had not been looking back at the cat, but had been constantly throwing one of the white pebble-stones out of his pocket on the road.

When they had reached the middle of the forest, the father said: "Now, children, pile up some wood, and I will light a fire that you may not be cold." Hansel and Gretel gathered brushwood together, as high as a little hill. The brushwood was lighted, and when the flames were burning very high, the woman said: "Now, children, lay yourselves down by the fire and rest, we will go into the forest and cut some wood. When we have done, we will come back and fetch you away."

Hansel and Gretel sat by the fire, and when noon came, each ate a little piece of bread, and as they heard the strokes of the wood-axe they believed that their father was near. It was not the axe, however, but a branch which he had fastened to a withered tree which the wind was blowing backwards and forwards. And as they had been sitting such a long time, their eyes closed with fatigue, and they fell fast asleep. When at last they awoke, it was already dark night. Gretel began to cry and said: "How are we to get out of the forest now?" But Hansel comforted her and said: "Just wait a little, until the moon has risen, and then we will soon find the way." And when the full moon had risen, Hansel took his little sister by the hand, and followed the pebbles which shone like newly-coined silver pieces, and showed them the way.

They walked the whole night long, and by break of day came once more to their father's house. They knocked at the door, and when the woman opened it and saw that it was Hansel and Gretel, she said: "You naughty children, why have you slept so long in the forest--we thought you were never coming back at all!" The father, however, rejoiced, for it had cut him to the heart to leave them behind alone.


Not long afterwards, there was once more great dearth throughout the land, and the children heard their mother saying at night to their father: "Everything is eaten again, we have one half loaf left, and that is the end. The children must go, we will take them farther into the wood, so that they will not find their way out again; there is no other means of saving ourselves!" The man's heart was heavy, and he thought: "It would be better for you to share the last mouthful with your children." The woman, however, would listen to nothing that he had to say, but scolded and reproached him. He who says A must say B, likewise, and as he had yielded the first time, he had to do so a second time also.

The children, however, were still awake and had heard the conversation. When the old folks were asleep, Hansel again got up, and wanted to go out and pick up pebbles as he had done before, but the woman had locked the door, and Hansel could not get out. Nevertheless he comforted his little sister, and said: "Do not cry, Gretel, go to sleep quietly, the good God will help us."

Early in the morning came the woman, and took the children out of their beds. Their piece of bread was given to them, but it was still smaller than the time before. On the way into the forest Hansel crumbled his in his pocket, and often stood still and threw a morsel on the ground. "Hansel, why do you stop and look round " said the father, "go on." "I am looking back at my little pigeon which is sitting on the roof, and wants to say good-bye to me," answered Hansel. "Fool!" said the woman, "that is not Your little pigeon, that is the morning sun that is shining on the chimney." Hansel, however, little by little, threw all the crumbs on the path.

The woman led the children still deeper into the forest, where they had never in their lives been before. Then a great fire was again made, and the mother said: "Just sit there, you children, and when you are tired you may sleep a little; we are going into the forest to cut wood, and in the evening when we are done, we will come and fetch you away." When it was noon, Gretel shared her piece of bread with Hansel, who had scattered his by the way. Then they fell asleep and evening passed, but no one came to the poor children. They did not awake until it was dark night, and Hansel comforted his little sister and said: "Just wait, Gretel, until the moon rises, and then we shall see the crumbs of bread which I have strewn about, they will show us our way home again." When the moon came they set out, but they found no crumbs, for the many thousands of birds which fly about in the woods and fields had picked them all up.

Hansel said to Gretel: "We shall soon find the way," but they did not find it. They walked the whole night and all the next day too from morning till evening, but they did not get out of the forest, and were very hungry, for they had nothing to eat but two or three berries, which grew on the ground. And as they were so weary that their legs would carry them no longer, they lay down beneath a tree and fell asleep.


It was now three mornings since they had left their father's house. They began to walk again, but they always came deeper into the forest, and if help did not come soon, they must die of hunger and weariness. When it was mid-day, they saw a beautiful snow-white bird sitting on a bough, which sang so delightfully that they stood still and listened to it. And when its song was over, it spread its wings and flew away before them, and they followed it until they reached a little house, on the roof of which it alighted; and when they approached the little house they saw that it was built of bread and covered with cakes, but that the windows were of clear sugar. "We will set to work on that," said Hansel, "and have a good meal. I will eat a bit of the roof, and you Gretel, can eat some of the window, it will taste sweet." Hansel reached up above, and broke off a little of the roof to try how it tasted, and Gretel leant against the window and nibbled at the panes. Then a soft voice cried from the parlor:

"Nibble, nibble, gnaw,
Who is nibbling at my little house?"
The children answered:

"The wind, the wind,
The heaven-born wind,"
and went on eating without disturbing themselves. Hansel, who liked the taste of the roof, tore down a great piece of it, and Gretel pushed out the whole of one round window-pane, sat down, and enjoyed herself with it. Suddenly the door opened, and a woman as old as the hills, who supported herself on crutches, came creeping out. Hansel and Gretel were so terribly frightened that they let fall what they had in their hands. The old woman, however, nodded her head, and said: "Oh, you dear children, who has brought you here Do come in, and stay with me. No harm shall happen to you." She took them both by the hand, and led them into her little house. Then good food was set before them, milk and pancakes, with sugar, apples, and nuts. Afterwards two pretty little beds were covered with clean white linen, and Hansel and Gretel lay down in them, and thought they were in heaven.

The old woman had only pretended to be so kind; she was in reality a wicked witch, who lay in wait for children, and had only built the little house of bread in order to entice them there. When a child fell into her power, she killed it, cooked and ate it, and that was a feast day with her. Witches have red eyes, and cannot see far, but they have a keen scent like the beasts, and are aware when human beings draw near. When Hansel and Gretel came into her neighborhood, she laughed with malice, and said mockingly: "I have them, they shall not escape me again!" Early in the morning before the children were awake, she was already up, and when she saw both of them sleeping and looking so pretty, with their plump and rosy cheeks, she muttered to herself: "That will be a dainty mouthfull" Then she seized Gretel. she smiled and said to herself."i should fattin you up befor i eat you."Then she went to Hansel, shook him till he awoke, and cried: "Get up, lazy thing, fetch some water, and cook something good for your Sister, she is to be made fat. When he is fat, I will eat her." Hansel began to weep bitterly, but it was all in vain, for he was forced to do what the wicked witch commanded.

The witch realized there was too much risk involved. The longer she kept Gretel around, the longer she had to keep Hansel around, and truth be told, he wasn’t worth it. Oh sure, she could have probably fattened him up down the road, but that was before little miss potbelly had just dropped on her doorstep, and the witch had a good feeling that there would be plenty more of her to go around. After all, she was a dim bulb. She didn’t suspect a thing. She’d eat herself round without having to think about it.

But the witch wasn’t going to reveal her plans just yet. She needed to catch Hansel and Gretel unawares.

“Boy, I’m going to send you to the market to go get me some ingredients,” she said, pulling Hansel aside. She handed him a bit of gold. “Now, you go and fetch the best price you can for a bag of sugar, got it?”

“Why can’t you just make some appear?” Hansel asked. “You’re a witch after all.”

“Because I said so, now get!” She pushed him out the back door.

She knew Hansel would of course not go to the market. He would try and go get help. Well, let him, she thought. He’d never be able to find this place again. Her magic would keep it well hidden. In the meantime, she had a feast to prepare for.
She opened Gretel’s cage and rolled her out. “Alright you, up at the table,” she said, pointing a crooked finger at the table in the kitchen loaded down with sweets.

Gretel whimpered. “What…what’s going to happen?”

“I’m going to eat you, that’s what,” the witch said. “But first, I want you good and stuffed before I put you in the oven. And don’t you dare think about making a sound, or I’ll eat you right now.”

Gretel nodded sadly and waddled over to the table. The witch grabbed the first dish of a plate of burgers and a heaping mound of fries. “Let’s get started,” she said wickedly.

The witch proceeded to hand-feed everything to Gretel. The poor girl barely got enough time to chew before the witch crammed more into her mouth. Before long, she had finished at least a dozen burgers, and the witch proceeded to plug her mouth with fries. “That’s right, piggie, eat up,” the witch cackled.

Tears started to form in Gretel’s eyes. This was technically her last meal, and oh, did it taste so good, but knowing what awaited her at the end made her wish she had never found this house in the first place.

Before long, the starch of the potatoes was starting to fill her belly, and she could feel the tightness building within. The witch kept stuffing her with more food. “I’m full!” she whined. “Please stop.”

The witch took a handful of her belly and squeezed. Gretel groaned. “Not nearly full enough yet!” the witch snapped. “You keep eating.”

Eventually, the witch moved on to all the sweets. She proceeded to fill Gretel’s stomach with a plate of brownies, a couple dozen cupcakes, and an entire cake. By the end of all that, Gretel was huffing and puffing, all the food packed into her stomach squeezing her insides. “No more,” Gretel cried, trying desperately to rub her taut middle, but finding her hands could not reach all the space they needed.

The witch poked and prodded her stomach, enjoying the squish of each pinch. “Oh, yes, my little porker. You’re stuffed to the brim,” she said, digging a finger deep in Gretel’s belly button. “I don’t think I could fit another bite in there. You know what that means? Time for the roasting pan.”

Gretel began to sob again, but the witch would hear none of it as she levitated Gretel into a roasting pan. She let Gretel get one last weigh in before being baked. “467,” the witch said. “Yum, yum, you are going to be a fat, juicy, and tasty morsel.”

She proceeded to baste Gretel in an oil, chop up some vegetables around her, stuffed an apple in her mouth, and coated a little bit of stuffing around her, putting a fat spoonful in her bowl-like belly button.

“Mm, mm, I can’t wait to eat you,” the witch said. “It’s been so long since I’ve had a good, fat, roasted girl like yourself. In you go.”

That had been a wonderful feast, she thought to herself as she rubbed her own fat gut, thinking of each and every savory bite. With a bit of magic, Gretel was prepared and eaten fairly quickly, at least long enough for the witch to eat without Laura noticing her absence. She heaved her bloated body around as she placed another helping of sweets on the table for Laura to enjoy.

“Here you are, sweetie,” the witch said, her voice dripping with honey. “I made far too much in the kitchen and I need your good little appetite to help finish them off.”

She leaned over to set the last plate of doughnuts on the table, her fat, squishy body pressing against Laura’s. She didn’t seem to notice. “Thanksh,” she said with a mouthful of food that she had already been eating.

Laura did do a bit of a double take. Was the old woman always that fat? She must be, she thought. After all, she was such a good cook. It was more than likely she would get fat off of her own cooking. Laura certainly was. She rubbed her belly, feeling its softness against her fingers. She was really making a pig out of herself, but the food was so good, and this woman was so nice. How could she resist? She began digging into the fresh batch of goodies the witch had left for her.

The witch plopped down into her biggest chair and let herself digest her own large meal. She hadn’t had a feast that great in ages, and it would be quite a while before she thinned out and was hungry again. Plenty of time for this fat porker to eat herself into a little round ball of fat.

As Laura continued to eat, the witch admired her plump little eater, who seemed to be getting plumper by the day. Her round face got even puffier, her neck being swallowed in a second chin. Her plump arms were starting to look like little pink hams. Her fat drumsticks had thickened and were looking particularly juicy. After all, she hadn’t told Laura the big secret yet, and the witch always loved that part when they figured out how much danger they were in.

The witch certainly had plenty to prepare for. Now with two delicious feasts on the way, there was so much more that needed to be done. She now needed to cook for two plump little butterballs, and even poor Hansel wasn't going to be that fast at keeping up with those appetites. Plus, the witch already was watering at the mouth thinking of what a delicious meal Laura would make, and she wanted to savor every moment of her fattening to herself.

In the meantime, she bid Hansel to continue feeding his sister. She wasn't off the hook just yet, after all. She saw to it that Hansel kept his sister good and fat while she waited on Laura to plumpen up.

After a few hours of cooking and keeping an eye on Hansel and Gretel, the witch finally went in to check on Laura, who was still devouring food at a rapid pace thanks to the spell.

"My, my, quite an appetite you've got, dear," the witch chuckled as she wheeled in another helping for the tubby young woman.

"Mmm, it's just so good," she grunted between bites. "I can't stop eating."

Indeed you cant, at least not until I say so, the witch thought, but continued sweetly. "That's wonderful to hear. After all, I'm going to need a nice, fat turkey this year. Let's just see how you're doing."

The witch proceeded to grab and knead Laura's soft, fat belly. Though it wasn't so soft anymore. Five solid hours of nothing but eating and she was starting to get incredibly stuffed. The witch would have to stop the spell temporarily, lest Laura bust a gut. That had happened once to a previous meal. It was not exactly tasty, and it was a hassle to clean up.

She made sure to take her time grabbing and squeezing Laura's growing love handles. It was like molding wet clay, she was so soft and pliable. The witch's eyes nearly rolled back in her head as she did so. She pinched Laura's chubby cheeks and ham-like arms. Oh, she was growing so well! Her thick thighs and round, juicy bottom were filling out just nicely. The witch was tempted to make her take a walk around the kitchen, just so she could watch it all undulate and jiggle. But, she couldn't risk this perfect dinner from having even a moment of exercise. She was simply stunning.

"Oh yes, I think you'll make a perfectly fat turkey in no time," the witch said, letting her fingers graze across the crest of Laura's belly, stopping just at her deep, thick belly button. Hm, now here was a problem. The poor girl's buttons on her skirt were starting to look strained. "Here, let me fix this," she said, undoing the buttons and letting Laura's pink, fleshy middle spill out. The witch licked her lips.

Laura didn't seem to see the danger in her situation. She puffed her belly out a bit, quite proud of herself. "Oh, I promise I'll eat well and be the biggest, fattest turkey you've ever had come to a Thanksgiving dinner."

"Oh, we'll see about that," said the witch. She was rather giddy at the prospect. "You know my last meal...I mean, guest was well over six-hundred pounds by the time Thanksgiving arrived. Think you can beat that in the next month?"

Laura nodded her head eagerly. "I think so. Just make sure you bring all your best cooking. Make it extra fattening if you have to. I've got a lot of catching up to do."

"Don't you worry about that. You know, let's see what you already weigh, my dear. Just step over here."

The witch scooted a scale over for Laura to step on with the minimal amount of activity needed. Laura tried to look over her own belly, but couldn't see past it. The witch laughed, poking her gently in the gut. "Now, now, don't get too eager. Let me look for you."

Bending down, she smiled wickedly. "284. My, my, you are already quite the little porker. Oh, but we'll have to do so much eating if we're going to be the biggest, fattest turkey, aren't we?"

She sat Laura back down, who was still quite hungry, thanks to the spell. "Let's have a little dessert first, and then we'll give you a rest," said the witch, pulling a box of glazed, cream-filled doughnuts from her cart. That would be just enough to see to it that Laura was stuffed for a while.

The witch proceeded to hand-feed Laura the delectible treats one by one, shoving each cream-filled, fried goodie down her throat, and watching it fill her perfect meal to the brim. Laura relished in the extra special attention and ate and ate, savoring each sweet bite, despite how packed her stomach was and telling her to not take another fattening bite. She couldn't help it. The food was just that good, and the thought of being an enormous, fat pig for this woman excited her like she had never felt before.

Just when the last bite had been pushed past her lips, the witch finally released her from the spell, and Laura was hit with the full feeling of being stuffed to the brim. "Ooh, I think if I ate anymore, I might pop," she groaned before yawning.

"Probably tired from all that excitement," the witch said. She snapped her fingers and a bed appeared right by the table. Laura didn't seem to notice. "You rest here tonight. I don't want my fat little turkey getting any exercise, you hear me? I want you to just eat and sleep, and my dear, I think you'll be quite delicious looking by Thanksgiving."

Laura obeyed, the hypnotic effects of the food not allowing her to see that something was clearly amiss. The witch tucked her in. "I'll be back in a few hours for some more to eat. I know you'll be good and hungry by then." She gave Laura's belly a light jiggle.

"Yeah, if I keep eating like this, I'll be hungry all the time."

"That's the idea. Now, sleep tight."

The witch went back to check on Hansel and Gretel before she turned in for the night. Gretel was still finishing her dinner feast that Hansel had cooked up. Gretel looked delicious as well, but not nearly as delectable as that fat morsel in the kitchen. Still, by the time she was done with Gretel, she would be just as tasty-looking.

"Don't you two think for a second you can escape. I've laid a spell on this house that won't allow you out, and I'll know if you try. You keep eating, and you keep cooking. I need my beauty rest."

"I don't believe that for a second, you silly girl, now eat up." The witch leaned in closer and whispered in her ear. "You'd better start eating, little porker, or I'm going to make you eat, and you wouldn't want to see that."

Gretel swallowed hard and went back to stuffing her face. The witch pretended to smile once more and started to head back to the kitchen. "Don't forget, Thanksgiving is only a couple of weeks away. I want two very, very fat turkeys I practically have to roll out the door."

Her expression quickly turned sour as she entered through the kitchen door. "At least one of them had better be," she grumbled. "What are you up to, boy? I told you to get cooking! You think I can keep those two fed at your snail's pace?"

Hansel glowered at the witch. "Well, knowing that you're just fattening up my sister to eat her, why should I go any faster?"

"Because if you don't, I'll eat her right now," the witch spat.

Hansel only glared at her. Her threats were starting to lose their punch. Hm, she needed a new tactic. A wicked little idea came into her head.

"Tell you what, this whole business with Laura has me thinking. I'll make you a deal. You help me make that delectable creature so fat, she can barely walk by Thanksgiving, and I'll spare your sister."

"Duh, I know that already. You already told us we have to play along and you won't eat her for a while."

The witch shook her head. "You're not listening, boy. I said I'd spare her, as in not eat her at all. But, here's the catch. You have to do an excellent job of fattening that Laura girl up, and I mean a damn good job. That'll at least keep me fed for a few months. It will take some time to digest her after all. In the meantime, your job will be to find me another morsel to fatten up in that time because once I get hungry, and you don't have a meal ready for me, I will eat your sister, got it?"

Hansel thought about it. "Does Gretel get to stop eating like a pig?"

She laughed. "No, stupid boy. She will continue to fatten because if you fail to get me another one to eat, I need a nice plump meal to satisfy my hunger."

"So, as long as I keep finding you more young women to fatten and eat, you'll leave Gretel alone?" Hansel wasn't going to lie, that was a tempting offer, but was he willing to put another person on the chopping block just to save his sister?

Who needed a gingerbread house when she had her own personal minion going around, finding, and fattening all her meals for her. The boy had some potential in him yet. In fact, she had quite a plan cooking up in her head.

In the meantime, Hansel was now the one delivering the food. "Uh, here you go, guys," he said. He went up and whispered in Gretel's ear. "Just play along. I think I've found our ticket out of this. I'll tell you about it later. You just eat a little bit at a time."

He got up closer to Laura, sitting beside her. "Wow, you really are getting fat," he said, trying to be nice and charming. "My aunt was right when she said you'd be the perfect turkey for my play."

Laura blushed. "Oh, well, thank you. I really am trying my hardest. Besides, I love this whole idea. I get to eat everything I want and not have to worry."

He laughed nervously. "Yeah. Look, I do want to get some measurements in before the show for your costume. Can you get on the scale first?"

She shoved the last piece of cake past her lips. "Of course. It's my favorite part of the day, well, besides the eating that is."

She stepped over on the scale and waited for Hansel to read off a number for her.

"455," he said.

Laura giggled and bounced on the balls of her feet, her fat mass jiggling with each movement. "Oh, that's just wonderful! I really am turning into quite the butterball."

"You sure are, now let me measure you."

Hansel took a tape-measure and wrapped around her waist. In truth, he was hardly paying attention. He just had to play this right. "Well, it's looking good, but you really have a long way to go. I'm worried you're not going to be big enough for the costume."

"Oh?" Laura looked worried.

Hansel smiled. "Don't worry, I'll help you out. Sit, and I'll make sure you eat so much you can hardly stand."

"Thanks, Hansel. You really are a sweetie. Sorry, Gretel, are we embarrassing you too much?"

"Not at all, you just worry about all this delicious food."

Hansel proceeded to spend the next few hours cramming as much food as he could into Laura's waiting mouth. He hated that he was doing this, but it was to save his sister after all. He helped Laura eat the mountain of pasta the witch had left for her, plenty of fried foods he had just brought out, another whole cake, a plate of brownies, and several dozens of cookies.

"Ooh, I'm so stuffed," Laura said. "You really know how to work a girl out. Can we take a break?"

Hansel knew the key to his sister's survival was keeping Laura fat, and so he started to worry. "But, we just got started, and you still have to gain another 150 pounds or more in the next couple of weeks. We can't stop."

"Hansel, I'm going to pop if I eat anymore. Please, just a little rest?" She batted her eyelids for emphasis.

He sighed. "Just a little. Here, let me help." He started giving her a soothing belly rub. Hopefully, that would help her digest faster so she could eat more.

"Oooh, that feels wonderful. Thank you, Hansel," she purred, starting to doze off.

Pretty soon, she was starting to fall asleep. That wasn't what Hansel was hoping for, but it would have to do until she could eat more.

"Okay, so tell me, what's all this about because I know you don't have a thing for Miss Too-Fat-to-Move."

Hansel sighed and explained to her the whole situation. "I know it's wrong, but it's the only way I can save you."

"It's not saving me, it's just prolonging the inevitable."

"No, that's just it. So long as I keep finding other girls for her to eat, you're safe."

"And then what if you can't? Or what if the witch doesn't keep her promise? Hansel this is wrong and you know it."

He continued to rub Laura's belly all the while. "It's the only way. Look, I'm worried too. I mean, the witch still has me cook and everything, so I don't know how I'm going to find the time to do all this, but I have to try."

"And what about me? I just have to keep eating and hoping I don't look too delicious enough for that witch?"

"We'll think of something," Hansel said. "Besides, I thought you said you liked being fat?"

Gretel huffed. "I do, but I don't like the idea of being eaten either."

"It's all we got. Just go with it for now."

Laura continued to sleep, her taut stomach already rumbling for more food. "I'd better get cooking for when she wakes up," Hansel said. "You should try and get some rest too."

Indeed, the witch had come up with a grand scheme, one she thought would pay off with great results. She had decided that as part of this plan, she would make Hansel her protege. She taught him a little magic, not enough to make him a threat to stop her, but just enough that he could use all the necessary spells he would need, like making food magically cook itself and spells that would make Laura hungrier. He would shape up to be a decent little warlock, and the best part: he worked for her.

With all the effort Hansel put into fattening Laura, she seemed to gain weight faster than ever. He made sure there was hardly a moment where she wasn't eating something. All the while, Gretel continued to eat, as part of her end of the bargain, but the extra pounds she put on were quickly being forgotten as Laura continued to balloon up.

A couple of days before Thanksgiving, and the witch was ready for her meal. She and Hansel went to the other end of the kitchen, where Laura was continuing to eat the feast Hansel had left for her the night before. She was enormous. Her perfectly fat belly now dominated her frame, hanging low, almost to the floor and cascading into several rolls. Her puffy arms were each the size of a Christmas ham. Her cushy bottom and wide as tree-trunk thighs were starting to warp the bench she was sitting on. And her puffy cheeks were crammed with food, giving her face a squinted look.

"Almost time for the big play, dear," the witch said. "We need to get you weighed one last time for your costume."

Laura hardly said a word, and only stopped eating when Hansel made the food disappear. She grunted in frustration, but tried to stand up, only to be met with a peculiar problem. She heaved and panted as she tried to lift herself, but found she couldn't do it. "I can't get up," she said.

The witch smiled. "Not to worry. We'll help you up." So with the help of Hansel, the two of them were able to lift the enormous pig to her feet and get her to stand on the scale, which crunched under her girth.

"732," Hansel read, quite surprised himself.

The witch gave her a pat on the belly. "That's my girl! You really are going to be my fattest turkey ever. Come, come now, let's get you all ready here on the counter."

"But the play's in a couple of days," she protested.

The witch waved it off with a spell, making Laura forget that the play was happening. "Nonsense, we need to get you stuffed and all ready."

The two of them heaved Laura onto the counter. The witch made a bowl of her special Thanksgiving stuffing appear out of nowhere and proceeded to feed Laura spoonful by spoonful. In the meantime, Hansel began helping her get Laura oiled up, have plenty of veggies sprinkled around her, and even stuffed an apple in her cavernous belly button.

"That tickles," Laura said between bites.

"Ah, ah, ah, you keep eating, my fat little turkey. We'll have you all ready in a moment."

"Ready for what?" Laura asked, starting to grow suspicious.

"Why, to eat you, of course," said the witch. "You foolish, child, you played right into my trap. You've eaten yourself so round, there's no hope of you getting away now. So, I'd just sit back, get stuffed, and just think about how delicious you'll taste."

Laura tried to struggle, but found it useless. The witch was right. She was too fat to run away. She lay there, panting in fear. The witch looked to Hansel.

"Well, what are you waiting for. My dinner's almost ready, which means, you should be out finding my next meal and getting her good and fat. Be gone with you!"

Hansel was glad to leave. He didn't want to see the witch eat Laura. The poor girl continued to grunt and whine, pleading for mercy while the witch plugged her mouth with more stuffing.

Gretel was meanwhile eating in the living room as Hansel made his way for the door. She had heard the sounds. "It's happening, isn't it?" she said worriedly.

"I'm afraid so."

"You're going to find another one, aren't you."

"Yes."

"Hansel?"

He looked back to her, tears in his eyes. "Yeah?"

"Please save me, Hansel," she said. "I know it's wrong, but I'm glad that's not me in there right now."

He nodded. "I'll do my best."

It didn’t take more than a couple of hours for Amber to arrive. The witch had cast a small spell that made her house easier to spot temporarily.

And indeed, Laura had lived up to her description of Amber. She was a little taller than Laura, but she was fat as could be. Her beautifully rounded potbelly looked like an overgrown pumpkin, and everything about her was plump and delectable, from her round chubby cheeks, to her fluffy, marshmallow-like arms, to her thick juicy drumsticks, to her fat little toes. The witch was already salivating at the thought of eating this one. And she would have gladly done so right then and there, but the prospect of making this pig even fatter was too tempting.

“Why come in, come in, my dear,” the witch said, guiding her into the room, taking a good grasp at her fat arms. “You must be Amber. Laura has told me so much about you.”

Amber smiled, easily taken in by the witch’s kindness. “I’m sure,” she said. “She told me you were the kindest woman and the best cook around. In case you haven’t noticed, I can’t resist good cooking.” She rubbed her squishy middle at the thought of it.

“Oh, I wouldn’t have it any other way,” the witch said. “I certainly do love good, fat, little eaters.” She proceeded to knead and poke Amber’s belly, admiring its softness. It practically jiggled like Jell-O in her grasp.

Amber laughed. “That’s just perfect then! She told me you were also putting on a cute little play. She said maybe I could help?”
“Indeed you could. I could always use some more fat turkeys for my play. Of course, we’ll need to get you good and plump for the role.”

She puffed out her gut. “Who could say no to that? Let’s get eating!”

The witch smiled. This was just too easy some days. Here, she had three fat little piggies who would eat themselves round just for her. That Big Bad Wolf had nothing on her.

“Ah, ah, ah, first we need to do a little measuring,” the witch said. She was dreadfully curious to know what she was working with here.

She brought Amber into the other room with Laura and Gretel who had both started to slow their feasting frenzy. Their bellies were looking good and stuffed.

“Alright, everyone,” she said. “We need to do a little bit of a weigh in. I want to see how my chubby turkeys are doing.”

Laura was eager and clapped her hands with excitement. “Oh, Amber, you’re here. Just in time too. I want to see how big I’ve gotten.”

Amber chuckled and gave her sister’s fat gut a pat. “You’ve certainly done some growing, sis.”
“Amber, you first, dear,” the witch said.

She hopped up onto the nearby scale. It whirred for a few seconds before settling on…

“350, right on the nose,” the witch said with delight. “You are a big girl, aren’t you? Well, you’d better have a seat and start filling that beautiful belly of yours. I want to see it twice its size by Thanksgiving.”

The girl strutted proudly to the table and began eating on what few bits of food Laura and Gretel hadn’t already eaten. Hansel watched from the kitchen, rolling his eyes as he went to cook more. How could the witch expect him to cook for three fat butterballs now?

Laura was next. “276,” the witch read. “Getting pretty chunky.” She pinched Laura’s lovehandles. “But, you’re going to have to eat quite a bit to be ready to be a good turkey.”

She yawned. “Can I take a nap first? I’m awfully tired, and awfully full.”

The witch shooed her off to bed. It would be a perfect time to make sure she wasn’t burning any calories.

Gretel was last. She winced as she heard the scale creak under her girth. But, eventually, the scales settled on…

“253,” the witch said. She gave Gretel a rough pinch. “I don’t think we’re eating nearly enough. Trying to trick me, eh? Well, you’d better start filling that gut to the brim, or I’m going to make you.”

Gretel sighed. “Yes…auntie,” she said, using their cover.

“Good, now go back to eating. You’re not nearly full enough.”

The witch headed back to the kitchen. She needed to get an ultimate feast ready to go for the three girls. Hansel was busy trying to keep up with it all.

“It wouldn’t kill you to help me,” Hansel said. “If you want Amber and Laura fat enough, you’re going to have to do some of the work yourself.”

“Hush, boy, or I’ll make you wish you never uttered a sound. I have a few tricks of my own, don’t you worry.”

“Here we are, girls, dessert!” the witch said, rolling in a trolley, stacked to the brim with all manner of cakes, pastries, cookies, brownies, pies, and cupcakes. Even the smallest cupcake weighed about two pounds, they were so chocked full of calorie-inducing ingredients and the potion.

And as each heavy treat passed their throats, their stomachs swelled out just that much more. Pretty soon, the fast-acting potion would turn it all to fat to spread around their bodies. Within an hour, the witch could tell that each girl looked a little wider, their hips flared out just that much more, their thighs that much thicker, their faces that much more chocked with fat. Even Gretel was not resistant to the spell and found herself grabbing more food, even though she knew that the fatter she got, the more delicious she was looking. It was so hard to resist.

A few weeks later, a new problem emerged.

“Urp…huff…huff…I can’t reach,” Amber wailed as her pudgy arms could not make contact with the food waiting for her on the table. Her gut had gotten so round, and her arms so flabby, she was unable to lean far enough to reach the next fattening treat.

The witch walked in the room, a devilish smile on her face. Before her was a fantastic sight. Three fat little doughballs with nowhere to go. Each one looked like a fat creampuff with arms and a head. She strode up to them. “My, my, what do we have here?” she said, poking and kneading Amber first.

“We…can’t…huff…reach…the…food,” Amber said. Her voice was so husky and her multiple chins made it a great effort for her to even talk.

“We’re too heavy,” Gretel finished. She was the only one of the three who knew how much trouble they were in.

“Well, but that’s a great problem to have, my little turkeys,” she said, taking a pinch of Laura’s pale, soft, wobbling belly. “It means you’ve gotten so round, and fat, and delicious.”

“Delicious?” Laura said, starting to get worried.

The witch knew she had them. Time to spring the trap. “Oh, my, yes, quite delicious. You see, my dear, I’m a witch, a witch who likes to eat fat little turkeys like yourselves. You three have been some of the best I’ve had. You’ve eaten yourselves so fat, there’s no way you can escape me now.”

Laura and Amber, now becoming aware of the danger looked around them, realizing for the first time all the purposefully fattening food and their now round, stuffed guts which weighed them down from running away. “You’re going to eat us!” they wailed.

The witch poked at Gretel for a few seconds. “Yes, that’s the idea. I was going to eat you last Thanksgiving, but I was having so much fun with my special potion to make you all eat more and more, that I decided to save you all for a year until the next Thanksgiving. That’s only a couple of weeks away, you know.”

The potion had put the girls into such a food-filled haze, they never realized they had been sitting there getting fatter by the day for an entire year. No wonder they couldn’t move. The witch would have to roll them to the oven.

“But, there’s still time, yet,” the witch said, “and I want the fattest of you three by that time for my feast. So, we’d better get busy.”

She snapped her fingers and the girls had been transported to a barn of some sort. Each had had their fat selves placed in a small sty, lying on their backs, belly up. The witch walked down the aisle of the barn. “Now, my little fatlings, for the next couple of weeks, I’m going to make sure you’re as fat as can be, and by Thanksgiving, I’ll eat one of you. The rest of you, I’ll save for much much longer to keep growing fat. After all, eating just one of you will keep me sated for quite a long time. Let’s begin.”

HARD BY a great forest dwelt a poor wood-cutter with his wife and his two children. The boy was called Hansel and the girl Gretel. He had little to bite and to break, and once when great dearth fell on the land, he could no longer procure even daily bread. Now when he thought over this by night in his bed, and tossed about in his anxiety, he groaned and said to his wife: "What is to become of us? How are we to feed our poor children, when we no longer have anything even for ourselves?" "I'11 tell you what, husband," answered the woman, "early to-morrow morning we will take the children out into the forest to where it is the thickest; there we will light a fire for them, and give each of them one more piece of bread, and then we will go to our work and leave them alone. They will not find the way home again, and we shall be rid of them." "No, wife," said the man, "I will not do that; how can I bear to leave my children alone in the forest--the wild animals would soon come and tear them to pieces." "0, you fool!" said she, "then we must all four die of hunger, you may as well plane the planks for our coffins," and she left him no peace until he consented. "But I feel very sorry for the poor children, all the same," said the man.
The two children had also not been able to sleep for hunger, and had heard what their step-mother had said to their father. Gretel wept bitter tears, and said to Hansel: "Now all is over with us." "Be quiet, Gretel," said Hansel, "do not distress yourself, I will soon find a way to help us." And when the old folks had fallen asleep, he got up, put on his little coat, opened the door below, and crept outside. The moon shone brightly, and the white pebbles which lay in front of the house glittered like real silver pennies. Hansel stooped and stuffed the little pocket of his coat with as many as he could get in. Then he went back and said to Gretel: "Be comforted, dear little sister, and sleep in peace, God will not forsake us," and he lay down again in his bed. When day dawned, but before the sun had risen, the woman came and awoke the two children, saying: "Get up, you sluggards! We are going into the forest to fetch wood." She gave each a little piece of bread, and said: "There is something for your dinner, but do not eat it up before then, for you will get nothing else." Gretel took the bread under her apron, as Hansel had the pebbles in his pocket. Then they all set out together on the way to the forest. When they had walked a short time, Hansel stood still and peeped back at the house, and did so again and again. His father said: "Hansel, what are you looking at there and staying behind for? Pay attention, and do not forget how to use your legs." "Ah, father," said Hansel, "I am looking at my little white cat, which is sitting up on the roof, and wants to say good-bye to me." The wife said: "Fool, that is not your little cat, that is the morning sun which is shining on the chimneys." Hansel, however, had not been looking back at the cat, but had been constantly throwing one of the white pebble-stones out of his pocket on the road.

When they had reached the middle of the forest, the father said: "Now, children, pile up some wood, and I will light a fire that you may not be cold." Hansel and Gretel gathered brushwood together, as high as a little hill. The brushwood was lighted, and when the flames were burning very high, the woman said: "Now, children, lay yourselves down by the fire and rest, we will go into the forest and cut some wood. When we have done, we will come back and fetch you away."

Hansel and Gretel sat by the fire, and when noon came, each ate a little piece of bread, and as they heard the strokes of the wood-axe they believed that their father was near. It was not the axe, however, but a branch which he had fastened to a withered tree which the wind was blowing backwards and forwards. And as they had been sitting such a long time, their eyes closed with fatigue, and they fell fast asleep. When at last they awoke, it was already dark night. Gretel began to cry and said: "How are we to get out of the forest now?" But Hansel comforted her and said: "Just wait a little, until the moon has risen, and then we will soon find the way." And when the full moon had risen, Hansel took his little sister by the hand, and followed the pebbles which shone like newly-coined silver pieces, and showed them the way.

They walked the whole night long, and by break of day came once more to their father's house. They knocked at the door, and when the woman opened it and saw that it was Hansel and Gretel, she said: "You naughty children, why have you slept so long in the forest--we thought you were never coming back at all!" The father, however, rejoiced, for it had cut him to the heart to leave them behind alone.


Not long afterwards, there was once more great dearth throughout the land, and the children heard their mother saying at night to their father: "Everything is eaten again, we have one half loaf left, and that is the end. The children must go, we will take them farther into the wood, so that they will not find their way out again; there is no other means of saving ourselves!" The man's heart was heavy, and he thought: "It would be better for you to share the last mouthful with your children." The woman, however, would listen to nothing that he had to say, but scolded and reproached him. He who says A must say B, likewise, and as he had yielded the first time, he had to do so a second time also.

The children, however, were still awake and had heard the conversation. When the old folks were asleep, Hansel again got up, and wanted to go out and pick up pebbles as he had done before, but the woman had locked the door, and Hansel could not get out. Nevertheless he comforted his little sister, and said: "Do not cry, Gretel, go to sleep quietly, the good God will help us."

Early in the morning came the woman, and took the children out of their beds. Their piece of bread was given to them, but it was still smaller than the time before. On the way into the forest Hansel crumbled his in his pocket, and often stood still and threw a morsel on the ground. "Hansel, why do you stop and look round " said the father, "go on." "I am looking back at my little pigeon which is sitting on the roof, and wants to say good-bye to me," answered Hansel. "Fool!" said the woman, "that is not Your little pigeon, that is the morning sun that is shining on the chimney." Hansel, however, little by little, threw all the crumbs on the path.

The woman led the children still deeper into the forest, where they had never in their lives been before. Then a great fire was again made, and the mother said: "Just sit there, you children, and when you are tired you may sleep a little; we are going into the forest to cut wood, and in the evening when we are done, we will come and fetch you away." When it was noon, Gretel shared her piece of bread with Hansel, who had scattered his by the way. Then they fell asleep and evening passed, but no one came to the poor children. They did not awake until it was dark night, and Hansel comforted his little sister and said: "Just wait, Gretel, until the moon rises, and then we shall see the crumbs of bread which I have strewn about, they will show us our way home again." When the moon came they set out, but they found no crumbs, for the many thousands of birds which fly about in the woods and fields had picked them all up.

Hansel said to Gretel: "We shall soon find the way," but they did not find it. They walked the whole night and all the next day too from morning till evening, but they did not get out of the forest, and were very hungry, for they had nothing to eat but two or three berries, which grew on the ground. And as they were so weary that their legs would carry them no longer, they lay down beneath a tree and fell asleep.


It was now three mornings since they had left their father's house. They began to walk again, but they always came deeper into the forest, and if help did not come soon, they must die of hunger and weariness. When it was mid-day, they saw a beautiful snow-white bird sitting on a bough, which sang so delightfully that they stood still and listened to it. And when its song was over, it spread its wings and flew away before them, and they followed it until they reached a little house, on the roof of which it alighted; and when they approached the little house they saw that it was built of bread and covered with cakes, but that the windows were of clear sugar. "We will set to work on that," said Hansel, "and have a good meal. I will eat a bit of the roof, and you Gretel, can eat some of the window, it will taste sweet." Hansel reached up above, and broke off a little of the roof to try how it tasted, and Gretel leant against the window and nibbled at the panes. Then a soft voice cried from the parlor:

"Nibble, nibble, gnaw,
Who is nibbling at my little house?"
The children answered:

"The wind, the wind,
The heaven-born wind,"
and went on eating without disturbing themselves. Hansel, who liked the taste of the roof, tore down a great piece of it, and Gretel pushed out the whole of one round window-pane, sat down, and enjoyed herself with it. Suddenly the door opened, and a woman as old as the hills, who supported herself on crutches, came creeping out. Hansel and Gretel were so terribly frightened that they let fall what they had in their hands. The old woman, however, nodded her head, and said: "Oh, you dear children, who has brought you here Do come in, and stay with me. No harm shall happen to you." She took them both by the hand, and led them into her little house. Then good food was set before them, milk and pancakes, with sugar, apples, and nuts. Afterwards two pretty little beds were covered with clean white linen, and Hansel and Gretel lay down in them, and thought they were in heaven.

Of course she was going to keep them all to herself. Screw the rest of her coven if they weren't having as fine luck as she. If they wanted meat, they needed to get off their lazy butts and do something about it. Rome wasn't built in a day, and her candy house sure as hell wasn't either.

Anna was the perfect little fatling. She did almost nothing but eat and sleep, and that was the way the witch liked it: fat, dumb, and lazy. She'd hit the trifecta. Never once did the girl suspect anything up, nor did she notice the magic in her food was making her forget that she only intended to stay the night. And it didn't take her long to start catching up to nearly the sizes of Hansel and Gretel.

And it was almost too easy. Anna had just finished polishing off a massive dinner that could've fed five people. As the witch walked in, a button popped off the latest outfit Anna had managed to stuff herself into that day. Looking at the floor, she saw that three or four other buttons had met that same fate. The round, pink ball of fat that was her belly started to spill out between the gaps. "That was delicious," Anna huffed, "better than the last time. I'm stuffed though."

The witch put on her best fake pout. "Oh, well, that can't be so," she said, setting down several trays. "Surely you've saved some room for dessert."

Indeed, the witch had set before her a small mountain of all manner of baked goodies. Anna's eyes seemed to light up at the thought of eating them. The witch had learned early on that baked sweets were the girl's weakness. "All of that for me?" she asked in disbelief.

The witch nodded. "Well, it was, but, as you said..." She poked Anna in the gut. It was certainly hard as a rock, but there was a little give in there. "You're stuffed. I suppose I'll just have to throw it all away."

5, 4, 3..., the witch thought to herself. "Wait," Anna said, biting her lip, and rubbing her belly with both hands, "I suppose I could find some more room. I mean, you did go to the trouble and all."

The witch smiled wickedly to herself. "That's my girl. Now here, let me help you."

The witch proceeded to open up the rest of Anna's shirt and helped her rub her belly to give her just a little more room. It was warm, soft, and oh so tender to the touch. She would make an excellent meal. If her fat little stomach wasn't enough, there was certainly plenty of rump roast to go around. And those succulent thighs! The witch could already feel her mouth watering at the thought of it.

Anna continued to stuff doughy good after doughy good into her mouth, and the witch knew it would only lead to a doughier her. Mm, just thinking about that well-marbled meat was making it hard for the witch to concentrate. Eventually, Anna polished off the last of the desserts and was now fast asleep, crumbs still on her cheek. The witch sighed contently and brushed them off, patted her belly, and watched this prized pig snooze. Before she left, she checked the back of the chair Anna was sitting in. It was rigged with a scale. 452 it read. Right on schedule.

But Anna wasn't the soul consumer of the witch's attention. There were still her other delicious morsels.

They had already lost their will to fight back, and they ceased to be stupid to her plans, so they had become quite boring, but she was able to find her fun somehow. Hansel stuffed himself like a Christmas goose at every meal she offered. He was desperate to save his sister, and so cared little for what he was eating. Just as well, the witch thought. She didn't really bother to put all that much effort into cooking his food. She just gave him an assortment of mashed, fluffy concoctions to insure a steady growth. By now, he filled up half the size of the stall, and the scale installed in the floor told her he was creeping close to the 500 mark. Oh, he wouldn't have much to worry about. When it came to her own personal meals, she preferred them nearly double that size.

Her fun came in taunting him. "Hm, certainly getting to be a big boy, Hansel," she laughed. "Had enough yet?"

He came up for air from his food. "No, more!" he called out, pure hatred in his eyes.

There was a menacing gleam in hers. "Just what I like to hear. At this rate, you'll be bigger than Gretel for sure." While she had long abandoned the idea of eating them at the coven feast and decided to wait until they each reached half a ton if not more before harvesting them, she still liked to let them think it was still part of the plan. They would have no idea how much time had passed.

"Anything to keep her from your clutches!" Hansel spat.

"Really?" the witch teased. "And just what did you think would happen after I was done eating you? That I would just suddenly let Gretel go? That someone would magically save her? Has all that food gone to your brain, boy? All you're doing is prolonging the inevitable."

He got real quiet, only absent-mindlessly eating his food. She really did love messing with his head. She nodded to herself, satisfied with her work, and left the fat little ball to continue eating. Gretel, on the other hand, was a different matter. Though she knew her fate, and though she knew what danger she was in, she still couldn't deny how good the food was. She savored every bite. The witch put a lot of time into cooking for her, even moreso than Anna. If Gretel wanted to go out with the culinary experience of a lifetime, then who was the witch to deny a last request?

Gretel was really only a few pounds behind her brother, and the two often bounced back and forth between who was growing the biggest. At the moment, Gretel was having the time of her life eating a massive dish of pasta with truffles. That was no small expense on the witch's part. She had to really work to find those.

The witch walked up to her, running her hands up and down Gretel's luscious curves. "How are we doing, my dear?" she asked sweetly.

Gretel hadn't been angry, so much as sad and scared. "I'm almost done with this," she said, sighing. "How's Hansel? Please, just tell me he's fine."

"Oh, he's coming along good," the witch muttered, squeezing Gretel's love-handles. "Very delicious indeed."

"Please stop! I don't want to hear you talking about him like meat."

The witch strode around her, kneading her soft fat with every word. "Darling, that's what he is. That's what you are. It's just the cold realities of life. Now, I bet a nice cheesecake will make you feel better about it."

The witch snapped her fingers, and a fresh tray wheeled in with the delectable dessert. Gretel's eyes widened, and she began to eat away her feelings. Oh, this had been a lucky few weeks, she thought.

12323.content:
It was already the next morning when Hansel and Gretel awoke, and they were more than just surprised by what they saw. At least six other children, four girls and two boys, were also in the room. Wait, was this still the same bedroom they had fallen asleep it? After a moment, they realized this was not the same room. It was much bigger, and had at least ten beds, room for two more kids, and had a massive dining table set in the middle of the room. It was also a very tall room with vaulted ceilings and windows that were very high up, not low enough to see out of, but there to give the room some natural lighting. But Hansel and Gretel took note of the other kids in the room. They were close to their own age and looked like they had just escaped the famine of the village too. The kids were already sat around the large dining table, digging in to a hearty breakfast. There were pancakes, dripping with syrup, several dozens of eggs prepared all sorts of ways, bacon, sausage, and ham, fresh from the pan, toast, and thick, fluffy biscuits dripping with butter. Hansel and Gretel found that their stomachs were already speaking for them. Only now did the other children notice them, so intent on eating the hearty meal. They gave a cheerful, but short greeting and went back to eating. “Wh-who are all of you?” Hansel asked.

The witch, who to the children still seemed like a dear, old woman, had entered and answered his question. “Oh, you’re not the first abandoned children I’ve taken in,” she said, “and it seems this famine is leaving more and more of you without homes. Not to worry. I have plenty, and you are all more than welcome to stay. I can’t stand the thought of sending you back into that harsh wilderness only to go back to a famine-riddled town. That’s no place for children.” She put on her most pitiful face as she punctuated that last sentence.

Hansel and Gretel looked at each other, seeming to have a silent conversation. Eventually, Hansel spoke up. “It would be wonderful to stay,” he said, “but it wouldn’t be too much trouble, would it?”

“Of course not,” she replied, “no trouble at all.”

“We would miss our father, though,” Gretel added, “but going home to more famine is probably not wise.”

“This is true,” the witch agreed, “and perhaps we may visit him some day, and bring some of our wonderful bounty to him. Now, dig in. Enjoy your first day here.”

Hansel and Gretel got up and properly made the acquaintance of the other inhabitants. There was William and Jacob, two identical twin brothers who hardly said more than “Have a seat” before stuffing their faces again. Cindy, the eldest of all the children was much more prudent and at least took the time to get to know Hansel and Gretel. She was a sweet girl who could at times be very maternal and protective. Martha was shy, but was at least curious about the new guests, and listened intently as they told their story. Ellie was a selfish sort, who was more concerned that there was not going to be enough food for her with two more mouths to feed. And Suzi hardly said a word. She seemed to be in some sort of eating trance.

All the children continued to eat, the food all so irresistible; too irresistible in fact. They had no idea just how long they had been eating, or that they had easily been helping themselves to fourth and fifth servings. They all attributed that to having had so little in their lives that they were just making up for lost time. However, they were reaching a stopping point, all too painfully stuffed to fit another bite in. The witch was only too kind to help them all up and back into bed, sometimes helping one rub their taut middles as she tucked them in.

That’s right, she thought, just eat and sleep for the first few weeks. The actual work, on her part would begin after they had had a few days to be lulled into a sense of security. For now, they would just be fat, dumb, and happy, just like all the others. She was already thinking about the one in the stalls out in the barn she was going to eat tonight. Oh yes, the witch had a rather effective piggy farm going. Once they reached a certain weight, she kept them in a pig sty in the barn until they were ready to eat. It would take several months to get this bunch to that point, but that was why she was so good at what she did. Timing was everything.
